mn41:11.1_0: Householders, principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of body, fourfold by way of speech, and threefold by way of mind.
mn41:12.1_0: And how is principled and moral conduct threefold by way of body?
mn41:12.2_0: It’s when a certain person gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.
mn41:12.3_1: They don’t, with the intention to commit theft, take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.

mn41:13.5_1: Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

mn41:2.1_0: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard:
mn41:2.2_0: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
mn41:2.4_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
mn41:2.5_0: With his own insight he has seen this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, and he makes it known to others.
mn41:2.6_0: He has a Teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end. It has a true goal and is well articulated. He sets out a perfectly complete and pure spiritual life.
mn41:2.8_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
mn41:3.1_0: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha.
mn41:3.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
mn41:3.1_2: While the Buddha were over, they sat down to one side, and said to him:
mn41:3.1_4: Before sitting down to one side, some of the Buddha and some bowed, while some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
mn41:3.1_5: Some of them sat down to one side,
mn41:3.1_6: Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side they said to the Buddha:
mn41:4.1_0: “What is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell?
mn41:4.2_0: And what is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”
mn41:43.2_0: ‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
mn41:43.3_0: It’s possible that this might happen.
mn41:43.5_0: That person behaves in a principled and just manner.”

mn41:44.4_0: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
